## Introduction

This R Markdown document demonstrates the use of plotnine for data visualization.

## Load Libraries

```{r libraries}
library(tidyverse)
# library(plotnine)  # Uncomment if using Python's plotnine via reticulate
```

## Load Data

```{r load-data}
# Load your data here
# data <- read.csv("path/to/your/data.csv")

# Example using built-in dataset
data <- mtcars
```

## Data Exploration

```{r explore-data}
# View structure of data
str(data)

# Summary statistics
summary(data)

# First few rows
head(data)
```

## Data Visualization

### Plot 1: Basic Scatter Plot

```{r plot-1}
ggplot(data, aes(x = wt, y = mpg)) +
  geom_point() +
  labs(title = "Scatter Plot: Weight vs MPG",
       x = "Weight (1000 lbs)",
       y = "Miles per Gallon") +
  theme_minimal()
```

### Plot 2: Colored by Category

```{r plot-2}
ggplot(data, aes(x = wt, y = mpg, color = factor(cyl))) +
  geom_point(size = 3) +
  labs(title = "Scatter Plot: Weight vs MPG by Cylinder",
       x = "Weight (1000 lbs)",
       y = "Miles per Gallon",
       color = "Cylinders") +
  theme_bw()
```

### Plot 3: With Regression Line

```{r plot-3}
ggplot(data, aes(x = wt, y = mpg)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = TRUE) +
  labs(title = "Scatter Plot with Linear Regression",
       x = "Weight (1000 lbs)",
       y = "Miles per Gallon") +
  theme_classic()
```

## Analysis

```{r analysis}
# Perform your analysis here
model <- lm(mpg ~ wt, data = data)
summary(model)
```
